choices.text: Less activity of epithelial sodium channels
Less vascular absorption of fluid due to caesarean section

questions.text: A neonate was delivered at 37 weeks by LSCS and developed respiratory distress in the form of tachypnea, with RR of 70/min, soon after birth. Chest X ray revealed fluid in interlobar fissure and the condition responded to oxygen therapy given for 12 hours, along with intravenous fluids. Which among the following is the likely pathophysiologic mechanism in such a child?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this child is Transient Tachypnea of newborn, i.e. TTN

Points in favour:

  • Term or near-term child delivered via LSCS
  • Tachypnea soon after birth
  • Fluid in interlobar fissure on radiology
  • Response to O2 therapy

Now, regarding mechanism of TTN, the concepts have undergone significant change in the past few years. According to Nelson 21st Ed, the normal clearance of fetal lung fluid occurs through increased expression of epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) and sodium-potassium adenosine triphosphatase (Na+, K+ -ATPase) that drive active sodium (and thereby fluid) reabsorption. TTN is believed to result from ineffective expression or activity of ENaC and Na+, K+ -ATPase, which slows absorption of fetal lung fluid and results in decreased pulmonary compliance and impeded gas exchange.

questions.text: A child with anemia is found to have the following peripheral smear finding. What is the likely possibility?
questions.solution: The peripheral smear is showing hypersegmented neutrophil. In megaloblastic anemias, a complete hemogram with red cell indices shows macrocytosis with MCV>110 fl and cytopenias. Hypersegmented neutrophils, with nucleus >6 lobes on peripheral smear may be seen.

questions.text: Anticipation phenomenon occurs in which of the following?
questions.solution: Anticipation is a pattern of inheritance in which symptoms became manifest at earlier ages and with increasing severity as traits are passed to subsequent generations. The genetic defect in myotonic muscular dystrophy is on chromosome 19 at the 19q13 locus. It consists of an expansion of the DM gene that encodes a serine– threonine kinase (DMPK), with numerous repeats of the CTG codon. Myotonic dystrophy often exhibits a pattern of anticipation in which each successive generation has a tendency to be more severely involved than the previous generation.

questions.text: Which among the following conditions presents in infancy with cycles of cyanosis appearing with a calm, resting child and cyanosis disappearing when the child cries?
questions.solution: Infants with bilateral choanal atresia who have difficulty with mouth breathing make vigorous attempts to inspire, often suck in their lips, and develop cyanosis. Distressed children then cry (which relieves the cyanosis) and become calmer, with normal skin color, only to repeat the cycle after closing their mouths.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of classic triad of clinical features seen in Apert syndrome?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of Apert syndrome comprises

  • Craniosynostosis
  • Mid-face hypoplasia
  • Bilateral syndactyly

Remember that Association with Chiari-I malformation is seen with Crouzon syndrome.

questions.text: A child with asymmetry between upper and lower limbs was evaluated and the following CXR finding was seen in the patient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The CXR is showing the typical 3-sign, seen in Coarctation of aorta. This is due to the constriction and post-stenotic dilation of the aortic arch distal to attachment of ligamentum arteriosum. CoA often shows hypertrophy in upper limbs and atrophy of lower limbs in long-standing cases.

questions.text: Major site of hemorrhage in preterm infants producing intraventricular hemorrhage is at which site?
questions.solution:
Most common type of CNS hemorrhage in preterm babies is Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH). Now obviously the question arises, Why?

  • IVH in premature infants occurs in the gelatinous subependymal germinal matrix.
  • This periventricular area is the site of origin for embryonal neurons and fetal glial cells, which migrate outwardly to the cortex.
  • Immature blood vessels in this highly vascular region of the developing brain combined with poor tissue vascular support predispose premature infants to hemorrhage.
  • The germinal matrix involutes as the infant approaches full-term gestation, and the tissue's vascular integrity improves; therefore IVH is much less common in the term infant.

questions.text: Optimal temperature of Neonatal ICU i.e. NICU according to guidelines should be?
questions.solution:
Remember the following temperature ranges, often marked wrongly by the students:

  • Delivery room temperature: About 25 Degrees C, with a range of 25 to 28 Degrees C
  • NICU temperature: 22 to 25 Degrees C

questions.text: A 3-months-old child presented to Pediatrics OPD with mother complaining of 'dirty - looking head' in the child since past few weeks. On examination, you found yellowish-white, greasy, asymptomatic scales and plaques on the scalp as shown below. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Yellowish-white asymptomatic greasy scales and plaques on scalp in an infant is suggestive of seborrheic dermatitis, also called cradle cap. The causative agent is Malassezia furfur. The condition responds to topical salicylic acid often combined with topical ketoconazole.

choices.text: Only Acyclovir to mother and baby
VZIG to both mother and baby but no acyclovir to be given
VZIG to baby + Acyclovir to mother as well as baby
Nothing active needed since child is asymptomatic

questions.text: An asymptomatic baby was born by LSCS at 37 weeks to a pregnant female who had developed chicken pox rash 18 hours prior to delivery. What is the optimum management?
questions.solution: Infants whose mothers demonstrate varicella in the period from 5 days prior to delivery to 2 days afterward are at high risk for severe varicella. These infants acquire the infection transplacentally as a result of maternal viremia, which may occur up to 48 hr prior to onset of maternal rash. Newborns whose mothers develop varicella during the period of 5 days before to 2 days after delivery should receive VZIG as soon as possible after birth. Additionally, acyclovir needs to be given to both mother and baby. Remember that neonatal varicella is a fulminant condition and needs to be aggressively prevented and managed, if develops.

questions.text: A 2700 gram baby delivered at 37 weeks, was well and exclusively breastfed. He was found to be icteric with a TSB of 14 mg/dl on day 5 of life. What is the management?
questions.solution:
In well-babies, delivered near term, the cut-offs to start PT are as follows:

  • 24 hr: ≥ 10 mg/dl
  • 48 hr: ≥ 13 mg/dl
  • 72 hr: ≥ 15 mg/dl
  • 96 hr and beyond: ≥ 18 mg/dl

Since in this baby the cut-off has not been reached yet, we need to simply observe the child and if needed, repeat the TSB value in another 24-48 hours if jaundice increases.

questions.text: Dubin Johnson syndrome and Rotor Syndrome can be distinguished on the basis of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Degree of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is not a relevant distinguishing point between the two conditions. All others can be used to distinguish the two conditions. Also remember the following:

Differences of Rotor Syndrome from DJS

  1. Unlike DJS, total urinary coproporphyrin excretion is elevated with a relative increase in the amount of the coproporphyrin I isomer.
  2. If liver biopsy is performed, there is no abnormal pigmentation in contrast to Dubin-Johnson.
  3. The gallbladder is normal on imaging in Rotor Syndrome, while it may be difficult to visualize in DJS

questions.text: Most common infectious cause of acute wheezing in a febrile child below 2 years of age?
questions.solution: Below 2 years of age, the most common condition causing fever and acute wheezing is Acute Bronchiolitis. The most common cause is Respiratory Syncytial Virus, RSV.

choices.text: Absence of head control can be a normal variant at this age
The child needs evaluation for development delay
Sitting with support may be delayed

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the 5 month old child shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The manoeuvre being performed here is “Pull to sit” and the child is showing significant head lag.

  • At 5 months of age, this type of head lag can not be a normal variant and thus option A is incorrect.
  • Options B and C are correct.
  • Regarding Option D, it is usually seen that children with significant head lag tend to have delayed gross motor milestones in general and thus sitting with support may also be delayed in this child, if the head/neck control is already delayed.

choices.text: IV Ringer's Lactate @ 30 ml/kg over 30 min

questions.text: A 4 year old child presented with loose watery stools, 8-9/day since last 2 days. The child is found to have features of severe dehydration but no shock. What is the immediate management to do in the next half hour?
questions.solution: Management of dehydration in children

choices.text: Lack of any associated congenital anomaly
Thyroid dysgenesis is most common cause
Prolongation of neonatal jaundice is an early sign

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding congenital hypothyroidism is false?
questions.solution:
Some nuggets regarding congenital hypothyroidism

  • Congenital hypothyroidism is most commonly caused by thyroid dysgenesis in 80-85% cases.
  • Birthweight and length are normal, but head size may be slightly increased because of myxedema of the brain.
  • The anterior and posterior fontanels are open widely; observation of this sign at birth can serve as an initial clue to the early recognition of congenital hypothyroidism.
  • Prolongation of physiologic jaundice, caused by delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation, is be the earliest sign.
  • Approximately 10% of infants with congenital hypothyroidism have associated congenital anomalies. Cardiac anomalies are most common, but anomalies of the nervous system and eye have also been reported. Infants with congenital hypothyroidism may have associated hearing loss.

questions.text: The following depiction of skin lesions is associated with which infection in children?
questions.solution:
The condition shown above is 'Dew drops on rose petal appearance.This is seen in patients with Varicella, i.e.Chicken Pox.

  • The usual case of varicella consists of mild systemic symptoms followed by crops of red macules that rapidly become small vesicles with surrounding erythema (described as a 'dew drop on a rose petal'), form pustules, become crusted, and then scab.
  • Pruritus may be intense;scarring occurs, but it is not common.
  • The rash appears predominantly on the trunk and face.
  • Lesions occur in the scalp, and sometimes in the nose, mouth(where they are nonspecific ulcers), conjunctiva, and vagina.
  • The magnitude of systemic symptoms usually parallels skin involvement.
  • Up to five crops of lesions may be seen.

questions.text: Not a feature of congenital zika syndrome?
questions.solution:
The five unique features of Congenital Zika syndrome include:

  • Severe microcephaly in which the skull has partially collapsed
  • Decreased brain tissue with a specific pattern of brain damage, including subcortical calcifications
  • Damage to the back of the eye, including macular scarring and focal retinal pigmentary mottling
  • Congenital contractures, such as clubfoot or arthrogryposis
  • Hypertonia restricting body movement soon after birth

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with multiple skin lesions, as shown along with ocular findings as depicted. What is the most likely tumour this child may develop?
questions.solution: The images show presence of numerous fleshy tumours, likely neurofibromas. The ocular picture shows multiple Lisch nodules. The findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis-1. The most common tumour in these patients are optic nerve gliomas. Remember that bilateral acoustic neuromas are a feature of Neurofibromatosis-2.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of cyanosis in first week of life?
questions.solution: TGA (Transposition of great arteries) is the commonest cause of cyanosis in the first week of life. TOF usually is a common cause of cyanosis beyond the neonatal period as well as overall, although it does present sometimes in neonates as well.

questions.text: All are features of DiGeorge syndrome, except?
questions.solution: In DiGeorge Syndrome, thymic hypoplasia is seen, not hyperplasia.

questions.text: Darkening of scrotum and development of glans penis occurs in which stage of sexual development in males?
questions.solution: SMR Staging in Males

questions.text: A 5-year old child as shown in the picture comes to OPD. He also has nystagmus, mild wrist drop, occasional petechiae and recurrent boils on the skin. What will you consider?
questions.solution:
Albinism, along with recurrent infections, bleeding manifestaions and neurological features are all suggestive of a diagnosis of Chediak-Higashi Syndrome.

  • High dose Vitamin C is effective
  • Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant, HSCT is curative.

questions.text: Cut-off of ESR in mm/hr to be taken as a minor criteria in the revised Jones criteria in moderate to high-risk population is?
questions.solution: Revised Jone’s criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever

questions.text: The mutation in cystic fibrosis, Delta F 508 belongs to which category of mutation?
questions.solution:
The most prevalent mutation of CFTR is the deletion of a single phenylalanine residue at amino acid 508 (F508del). This mutation is responsible for the high incidence of CF in northern

European populations and is considerably less frequent in other populations, such as those of southern Europe and Israel. Class II mutations cause retention of a misfolded protein at the endoplasmic reticulum and subsequent degradation in the proteasome. F508del belongs to this category.

questions.text: Which study is the most important to obtain in a 2-year-old child with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome other than an ultrasound?
questions.solution: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is characterized by neonatal overgrowth. Infants are large for gestational age, have macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, and often difficult to control hypoglycemia. Children with this disorder are at increased risk for development of Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, and adrenocortical carcinoma. Serum alpha-fetoprotein is elevated in about 90% of patients with hepatoblastoma. Thus, all children with this syndrome need USG-KUB and Serum AFP level measurement.

questions.text: An irregular red reflex is noted on the initial examination of an infant. The infant is referred to the ophthalmologist for evaluation of a cataract. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with a cataract in the newborn?
questions.solution: The differential diagnosis for cataracts identified in the neonatal period is wide and includes developmental disorders, congenital infections, and metabolic disorders. Galactosemia, a disorder of carbohydrate metabolism, should be a primary consideration in a neonate presenting with cataracts.

questions.text: A male child with congenital heart disease also has anti-mongoloid slant of eyes and hypogonadism. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Key Features of Noonan syndrome

  • Antimongoloid slant of eyes
  • Short stature
  • Webbed neck
  • Hypogonadism
  • Congenital heart disease: Pulmonic stenosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not consistent with Kwashiorkor?
questions.solution: Baggy pants appearance is seen in Marasmus, due to loss of subcutaneous fat in the thighs and buttocks. It is not seen in children with Kwashiorkor.

questions.text: In a child vaccinated for HBV, one year later the serology will show which among the following pattern?
The abdominal mass in a child with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best felt at?
questions.solution: According to Nelson 21st Ed, 'the diagnosis has traditionally been established by palpating the pyloric mass.The mass is firm, movable, approximately 2 cm in length, olive shaped, hard, best palpated from the left side, and located above and to the right of the umbilicus in the mid epigastrium beneath the liver's edge.'

questions.text:
An infant is found to have rash as shown below.


Which micronutrient deficiencies can produce such a clinical picture?
questions.solution:
The findings are consistent with a diagnosis of zinc deficiency, as seen in acrodermatitis enteropathica.

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by an inability to absorb sufficient zinc from the diet.
  • The genetic defect is in the intestinal zinc-specific transporter gene
  • Initial signs and symptoms usually occur in the 1st few months of life, often after weaning from breast milk to cow’s milk.
  • The cutaneous eruption consists of vesiculobullous, eczematous, dry, scaly, or psoriasiform skin lesions symmetrically distributed in the perioral, acral, and perineal areas and on the cheeks, knees, and elbows.

questions.text: Object permanence develops at what age in a child?
questions.solution: Object permanence is the ability of a child to understand that object continues to exist even when not visible. This develops by 9 months of age.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child has a temperature of 104°F (40°C) for 4 days without other signs. On the fourth day a rose pink, maculopapular, non-itchy rash appears on the trunk within 12 hours of the temperature returning to normal. What is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution: High fever without other signs and clearing of the fever on appearance of a rash are characteristic of roseola infantum and is the defining clinical expression of primary infection with human herpes virus 6. The rash in such patients is additionally non-itchy and appears first on the trunk. In measles infection, fever continues for several days after the appearance of the rash and doesn’t show the progression as described. Varicella rash is itchy and lesions occur in crops, evolving into vesicles.

questions.text: The neonate shown in the picture died at 6 hours of life despite intubation and early mechanical ventilation. Autopsy revealed bilateral renal agenesis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Association of bilateral renal agenesis, respiratory failure and limb defects, as seen in the picture suggests a diagnosis of Potter Syndrome. These children have severe pulmonary hypoplasia and in utero oligohydramnios.

choices.text: Repeat dose of IVIG at 2 g/kg

questions.text: An 8 year old child with acute ITP presented with severe acute mucosal bleeding, for which the child was hospitalized. He had a blood group of B-ve. He was given one dose of IVIG @ 0.8 g/kg and given 5 days course of oral prednisolone @2 mg/kg/day but there is still platelet count less than 7000/mm3 with features of active mucosal bleeding. What second-line therapy is to be considered in this child?
questions.solution:
According to American Society of Hematology guidelines, in acute ITP pediatric patients not responding to first line management comprising IVIG/Steroids/Anti-D, the preferable 2nd line agents include TPO receptor agonists like

  • Romiplostim
  • Eltrombopag

choices.text: Physiological short stature and pathological short stature
Bone age and height age patterns

questions.text: All of the following can be used to distinguish familial short stature from constitutional delay in growth except?
questions.solution:
Both conditions have height for age below -2 SD of the population mean for age and sex and are categorised as Physiological short stature. Thus, this point can not be used to differentiate the two conditions.

Also remember the following

questions.text: Which among the following therapy is drug of choice for apnea of prematurity?
questions.solution: Doxapram is avoided in apnea of prematurity. Others are known respiratory stimulants, with caffeine citrate being the drug of choice.

questions.text: A neonate presented with severe cardio-pulmonary complaints in the first week of life and was stabilized using Alprostadil intravenous infusion. All of the following conditions are ductus dependent lesions responding to alprostadil except?
questions.solution: Obstructive TAPVC is not a ductus dependent lesion and tends to worsen on giving Alprostadil, i.e. PGE1 intravenous infusion. This is because opening ductus arteriosus in obstructive TAPVC compromises the pulmonary blood flow and diverts cyanotic deoxygenated blood more into the systemic circulation. All others are known cases of ductus dependent congenital heart diseases which improve with Alprostadil.

questions.text: Petechiae on junction of soft and hard palate are seen in?
questions.solution: Symptomatic EBV infections in older children and adults are characterized by insidious onset with symptoms such as malaise, fatigue, fever, headache, nausea, sore throat, abdominal pain and myalgia. Examination shows pharyngeal inflammation with exudates and petechiae at the junction of soft and hard palate, generalized lymphadenopathy (cervical, less often axillary and inguinal), mild splenomegaly (50%) and hepatomegaly (10%). Maculopapular rashes are seen in 3-15% and in 30% of those who have received ampicillin or amoxicillin.

questions.text: What is the cut-off of venous hematocrit to start partial exchange transfusion in a case of neonatal polycythemia when the child has frequent apneic episodes and feeding difficulties?
questions.solution:
Please note that any symptomatic neonatal polycythemia always needs Partial exchange transfusion.

Things to remember:

  • Neonatal Polycythemia: Venous hematocrit ≥ 65%
  • Treatment:
  • Asymptomatic neonate
    • PCV<70%: Observation and monitoring
    • PCV 70-74%: Hydration
    • PCV ≥ 75%: Partial exchange transfusion, i.e. PET

choices.text: Aberrant origin of Left Coronary Artery

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with irritability and congestive heart failure. An ECG is interpreted as characteristic of myocardial infarction. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution: In the congenital abnormality of anomalous origin of the left coronary artery (LCA), the aberrant LCA arises from the pulmonary artery rather than from the aorta. This results in perfusion of the left ventricle by poorly oxygenated blood under low pressure. Myocardial ischemia can be severe. The presenting signs are irritability and congestive heart failure. The age at presentation is related to the degree of collateral circulation between the LCA and RCA.

questions.text: Quadrupling of birth weight occurs at?
questions.solution: Doubling of birth weight occurs at 5 months, tripling at 12 months and quadrupling at 24 months, i.e. 2 years of age.

questions.text: Cut-off to define steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome in children as per latest guidelines?
questions.solution: According to Indian Society of Pediatric Nephrology 2021 guidelines, Steroid resistance in childhood nephrotic syndrome is now to be defined as- Absence of complete remission of proteinuria despite 6 weeks of daily steroid therapy.

questions.text: The mother of a 3-year-old boy reports that he is 'on the go' all the time. Typically, children stop taking daytime naps at which of the following ages?
questions.solution: Even during the neonatal period, up to 10 of an infant’s average of 16 hours of sleep per day are concentrated at night. This is reflective of an adaptation process which began in the third trimester of pregnancy. Daytime sleep progressively declines in infancy; the 12-month-old typically takes two 1-hour naps during the day. By the age of 3, most toddlers sleep 1 hour during the day, and the majority of 4-year-olds do not take a daytime nap.

questions.text: You suspect the diagnosis of Werdnig-Hoffman disease in an infant with severe hypotonia. Which other finding will support this diagnosis?
questions.solution: Werdnig-Hoffmann disease is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the anterior horn cells and the motor nuclei of the brainstem. Loss of motor function begins in infancy and progresses fairly rapidly, leading in most cases to ventilatory failure within the first 2 years of life. Clinical features include hypotonia, weakness or paralysis, hyporeflexia, and muscle fasciculations, which are most readily noted in the tongue. Seizures, optic atrophy, and fever are not features of this disorder. There also is a rare, late-onset, more slowly progressive degenerative disorder of the anterior horn cells referred to as Kugelberg-Welander disease.

questions.text: The following method is useful for which among the following?
questions.solution: The method shown in the image is Dried blood spot, i.e. DBS method, used for screening of IEMs. Utilizes dried blood from heel pad prick taken from neonates. Tandem mass spectrometry or TMS is used to analyse the specimen.

choices.text: Runs, rides tricycle, skips, hops on one foot
Runs, hops on one foot, skips a rope, rides tricycle
Runs, rides tricycle, hops on one foot, skips a rope
Hops, skips, rides tricycle, rides bicycle

questions.text: The grandfather of a 1-year-old brings him in for a checkup and states that the boy received a tricycle for his first birthday but wonders when he will be able to pedal to ride it. Which of the following sequence best demonstrates the correct attainment of motor milestones?
questions.solution: Most children begin to walk independently around the time of their first birthday; some do not walk until 15 months. At 18 months of age, the infant shows improvements in balance and agility, and can run independently. By 3 years of age, the child has attained the motor coordination to ride a tricycle. A child is usually hopping on one foot by 4 years of age and skipping a rope by 5-6 years of age. Riding a bicycle is a complex interplay of skill and coordination and is usually not considered a development milestone.

questions.text: A 10-years old boy rapidly developed hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination revealed raised levels of lactic acid and uric acid. On examination, liver and both kidneys were found to be enlarged. Histopathology of liver showed excess deposits of glycogen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Points in favour of Von-Gierke disease

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Increased uric acid levels in the blood
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Renomegaly
  • Excess glucagon deposition in the liver

Remember that Cori’s disease resembles Von Gierke disease but shows no renomegaly, no lactic acidosis or hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A child with abdominal mass is found to have an appearance as shown below, along with episodes of hypertension and increased sweating. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Points in favour of Neuroblastoma

  • Abdominal mass
  • Episodic hypertension and increased sweating suggestive of a tumour producing vasoactive substances
  • Raccoon eyes bilaterally due to orbital i.e. bony metastasis
